questions.text: Chauffeur’s fracture involves the
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fracture of radial styloid with intact radiocarpal joint anatomy is called as Chauffeurs fracture/Hutchinson fracture/Backfire fracture

questions.text: A patient with history of fall on outstretched hand will most probably have injury to which of the marked area in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Fall on outstretched hand is a common mechanism of distal end radius fracture known as colles fracture. Option B-injury to ulna is seen in monteggia and nghtstick fracture. Option C,D-capitate and 3rd metacarpal are not commonly injured due to fall on outstretched hand.

questions.text: A 4-years-child is brought to emergency with complain of severe pain in arm after a fall, immediate X-ray done shows fracture distal radius and ulna. Which of the following term best describes the fracture:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Torus / buckle fracture is buckling of cortex classically occurring at metaphysiodiaphyseal junction. Option B-Greenstick fracture-one cortex breaks and other cortex remains intact resulting in fracture of distal radius and ulna. Option C-Barton’s fracture is intraarticular fracture of distal radius with radiocarpal joint subluxation with intact styloid. Option D-Colles fracture is fracture of distal end of radius with dorsal displacement of distal fragment.

questions.text: Most common bone to be fractured in children is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Supracondylar fracture of humerus is the M/C elbow fracture in children Radius/ulna fracture is the M/C fracture overall in children (Green stick fracture).

questions.text: Madelung’s deformity involves:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Madelung’s deformity involves distal radius and closest D/D is malunited distal radius fracture.Madelung deformity is a developmental or acquired deficiency of the volar-ulnar aspect of the distal radius. This condition can lead to a cosmetic or functional wrist deformity.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this fracture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal ulna with dislocation of the radial head. Option B-Sideswipe injuries constitute a subgroup of complex elbow trauma. Option C-Galeazzi fracture is a fracture of the distal radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ). Option D-A Colles' fracture is a type of fracture of radius in which the broken end of the radius is bent backwards.

questions.text: Name of the fracture for which this surgery is done :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given X ray shows plating in radius (indicating fracture radius) with K wire across distal radio-ulnar joint ( DRUJ dislocation ), thus the diagnosis is Galleazi fracture. Option B-Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal ulna with dislocation of the radial head. Option C-Wrist subluxation is not treated in this way. Option D-Fracture ulna is not shown in the giuven X-ray.

questions.text: Posterior interosseous nerve is injured in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Posterior dislocation of elbow usually do not cause injury to Posterior interosseous nerve. Option B-Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal ulna with dislocation of the radial head.In Monteggia fracture , most common nerve injury is that of Posterior interosseous nerve . Option C-Reversed Monteggia fracture dislocation/Galeazzi fracture is a fracture of the distal radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ). Option D-In Supracondylar fracture of humerus,MC nerve injured is anterior interosseous nerve

choices.text: Volar angulation with Radius deviation occurs
It is an intra articular fracture
It may lead to gunstock deformity due to Malunion
It is associated with dorsal angulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Colles fracture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Volar angulation occurs in smith fracture. Option B-Colles fracture is a extraarticular fracture. Option C-supracondylar fracture may lead to gunstock deformity due to Malunion. Option D-Colles fracture is associated with dorsal angulation.

questions.text: Commonest fracture in elderly with fall on outstretched hand is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Colles fracture is the M/C fracture in elderly with fall on outstretched hand. Option B- Bennetts fracture refers to an intraarticular fracture that separates the palmar ulnar aspect of the first metacarpal base from the remaining first metacarpal. Option C-Galeazzi fracture is a fracture of the distal radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ). Option D-Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal ulna with dislocation of the radial head.

questions.text: Most common complication of Colles?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Joint/finger stiffness > malunion is the Most common complication of Colle's fracture. Option B-Avascular necrosis is usually not seen in colles fracture. Option C-Joint/finger stiffness > malunion is the Most common complication of Colle's fracture. Option D-Rupture of EPL tendon is seen in colles fracture but its not the Most common complication of Colle's fracture.

questions.text: A lady presented with Colle's fracture. The fracture healed but after few days patient develops pain and swelling over wrist and forearm, red hot and shiny skin and on X- Ray patchy osteopenia is seen. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-pain and swelling over wrist and forearm, red hot and shiny skin and on X- Ray patchy osteopenia is seen.This Clinical picture is characteristic of Sudeck’s osteodystrophy. Option B-Causalgia, officially known as complex regional pain syndrome type II, is a pain syndrome characterized by severe burning pain, motor and sensory dysfunction, and changes in skin color and temperature sensation distal to an injured peripheral nerve. Option C-colles fracture goes into malunion. Option D-Nerve injury is usually not seen in colles fracture.

questions.text: Sudeck’s dystrophy symptoms are all except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A,C,D-Sudeck’s dystrophy is characterised by Pain,Stiffness and Sweating. Option B- There is osteopenia due to increased blood flow, not increased bone density.

questions.text: Stellate ganglion block is useful in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Stellate ganglion block is useful in Sudeck’s osteodystrophy for pain management and also the disease process, as it is believed that, the disease is due to sympathetic overactivity. Option B,C.D-Compound palmar ganglion,Tenosynovitis and Osteoarthritis of first CMC joint are not treated by Stellate ganglion block.

choices.text: Is a severe from of Colles’ fracture

questions.text: Barton’s fracture of the wrist?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-This is an intra-articular fracture of Distal end of radius in which carpus and a rim of distal radius are displaced together, thus it is fracture dislocation. Option B-A Colles fracture is a complete fracture of the radius of the forearm close to the wrist resulting in an upward (posterior) displacement of the radius and obvious deformity.however colles is an extra articular fracture. Option C-It is often treated by surgery.

choices.text: It is the most commonly fractured carpal bone
Persistent tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox is highly suggestive of fracture
Immediate X- ray of hand may not reveal fracture line

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is not correct regarding fracture of the scaphoid?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-It is the most commonly fractured carpal bone. Option B-Persistent tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox is highly suggestive of fracture scaphoid. Option C-Immediate X- ray of hand may not reveal fracture line.however it maybe seen after 1-2 weeks due to bone resorption during fracture healing. Option D-M/C complication is Non union (Hump back deformity) > AVN. Malunion is rarely seen.

questions.text: One of the common fracture that occur during boxing by hitting with a closed fist is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal ulna with dislocation of the radial head. Option B-Galeazzi fracture is a fracture of the distal radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ). Option C-Bennetts fracture is common in boxers while hitting with a closed fist, but the fracture M/C in boxers is Boxers fracture. Option D-Smith's Fracture is a fracture of the distal end of the radius caused by a fall on the back of the hand (flexed), resulting in a volar displacement of the fractured fragment. It is also known as a reverse Colles fracture. (Note-Boxer's fracture refers specifically to a break in the fifth metacarpal (the bone in the hand corresponding to the pinky finger), typically resulting from punching an object with a closed fist. It’s a common injury among boxers and others who punch things with improper technique or excessive force)

questions.text: Boxer’s fracture is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Radial styloid fracture is seen in chauffers fracture. Option B-Reverse colle’s fracture is another name for smith fracture. Option C-Fracture neck of 5th metacarpal is Boxers fracture. Option D-1st metacarpal fracture is seen in barton fracture.

questions.text: Rolando fracture involves base of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rolando fracture is V or Y or T shaped intra-articular fracture of base of 1st metacarpal.

questions.text: Lateral epicondylitis elbow begins in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lateral epicondylitis elbow/Tennis elbow is chronic tendinitis of common extensor origin of elbow. Mainly it begins with microtear in the substance of ECRB origin.

questions.text: De Quervian’s tenovaginitis involves tendons of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) De Quervian’s tenovaginitis is Stenosing tenosynovitis of the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) tendon (1st dorsal compartment).

questions.text: Dupuytren’s contracture is fibrosis of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It is proliferative fibroplasia of subcutaneous palmar tissue (palmar aponeurosis) in form of nodules and cord that may result in flexion contractures in fingers and palm

choices.text: A feature of carpal tunnel syndrome
Injury to fingers while operating a gun
Stenosing tenovaginitis of flexor tendon of affected finger

questions.text: Trigger finger is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) It is a stenosing tenovaginitis of flexor tendon of the affected finger which may lead to entrapment of the tendon at A1 pulley at the level of MCP joint resulting in flexion deformity of finger.

questions.text: Most common cause of trigger finger:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Causes of trigger finger are:- Trauma(Most common cause of trigger finger) Rheumatoid arthritis Gout diabetes

questions.text: In trigger finger, level of tendon sheath constriction is found at the level of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) It is a stenosing tenovaginitis of flexor tendon of the affected finger which may lead to entrapment of the tendon at A1 pulley at the level of MCP joint.

choices.text: Initially joints are mobile followed by rigidity
Flexion at PIP joint and extension at DIP

questions.text: True about Boutonniere deformity is/are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-It is due to rupture of the central extensor expansion of the fingers. Option B-In Boutonniere deformity, Initially joints are mobile followed by rigidity Option C-Boutonniere deformity is Flexion contracture of PIP joints and extension of DIP joint as shown below. Option D-All of the above are correct.

questions.text: Pulley involved in trigger finger:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It is a stenosing tenovaginitis of flexor tendon of the affected finger which may lead to entrapment of the tendon at A1 pulley at the level of MCP joint.

questions.text: Jersey finger is caused by rupture of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Disruption of Flexor Digitorum Profundus (FDP) tendon from its insertion at the volar aspect of the distal phalanx is called jersey finger.

choices.text: Surgical repair of the flexor tendon

questions.text: A 30-year-old man involved in a fight, injured his middle finger and noticed slight flexion of DIP joint. X-rays were normal. The most appropriate management at this stage is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Ignoring the deformity can lead to contracture formation. Option B-Based on clinical features of slight flexion of DIP joint, the diagnosis is mallet finger which is managed by splintage in hyperextension. Option C-Surgical repair of the flexor tendon can be done in refractory cases. Option D-Buddy strapping keeps the finger straight,but here we want splintage in hyperextension.

choices.text: Ulnar collateral ligament injury of MCP joint
Radial collateral ligament injury of MCP joint
Radial collateral ligament injury of CMC joint
Ulnar collateral ligament injury of CMC joint

questions.text: Game Keeper’s thumb is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Injury to thumb metacarpo-phalangeal joint ulnar collateral ligament.

questions.text: Olecranon bursitis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Tennis elbow-common extensor origin at lateral condyle of humerus. Option B-Golfer’s elbow – common flexor origin at medial condyle of humerus. Option C-Student’s elbow-Olecranon bursitis. Option D-Little league elbow – valgus overload/ overstress to medial elbow.

questions.text: A patient with the history of trauma, a year back , comes with complain of wrist pain and the following X-ray, diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Kohlers disease is osteochondritis of navicular bone. Option B-Keinbock’s disease is osteochondritis of lunate bone Option C-X-ray shows Fracture through the waist of scaphoid, with sclerosis of proximal part of scaphoid with normal distal part points to diagnosis of post-traumatic AVN of scaphoid. Option D-A Colles fracture is a complete fracture of the radius bone of the forearm close to the wrist resulting in an upward (posterior) displacement of the radius and obvious deformity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the crush syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Massive crushing of muscle leads to myohemoglobinemia and then myohemoglobinuria which in turn may lead to acute tubular necrosis. Option B-Crush syndrome is so named because there is massive crushing of tissues such as muscles. Option C-myohemoglobinuria in turn may lead to acute tubular necrosis. Option D-However, bleeding diathesis is not a feature of crush syndrome

choices.text: Decrease capillary refill in the fingers of the patient
Patient with weakness of wrist extensors
Patient with abrasion >10cm over the fracture site.

questions.text: Some patients present with injury in casualty. Which of these needs to be first evaluated by the orthopedician?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-This is an emergency situation and needs to be evaluated first as if vascular injury is present, it needs to be managed within 6 hours .otherwise gangrene can occur. Option B-patient having Fracture with intra articular extension needs evaluation but among the given options he`s not the first priority. Option C-Patient with weakness of wrist extensors also needs evaluation to rule out nerve injury but among the given options he`s also not the first priority. Option D-Patient with abrasion >10cm over the fracture site can also wait as abrasion is a kind of simple injury.

questions.text: Dequervain’s disease is inflammation of ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B-It is the inflammatory tenosynovitis of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.De Quervain's tenosynovitis is swelling of the tendons that run along the thumb side of the wrist and attach to the base of the thumb. This occurs when the tendons are constricted by the sheath that they run through to get from the wrist to the hand. Finkelstein test can be done which involves placing your thumb in your palm, grasping it with your other fingers, and bending your wrist toward your little finger. The test is positive, indicating you may have De Quervain's tenosynovitis, if you experience pain during the maneuver.

choices.text: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia and deep fascia

questions.text: In fasciotomy for compartment syndrome which structures are released ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D-Complete release of fascia is important to decompress the closed compartment of increased pressure.Hence deep fascia should be cut to relieve the pressure withing the compartment formed by deep fascia.

choices.text: Blood supply enters through the waist
Blood supply enters though the distal pole

questions.text: Avascular necrosis is seen at proximal pole of scaphoid because?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Blood supply to scaphoid enters through distal pole, supplying it distally and vessels turn in retrograde direction to supply the proximal bone, as end arteries.hence,Avascular necrosis is seen at proximal pole of scaphoid.

questions.text: In elbow, Osteonecrosis usually involves?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Capitulum is the M/C site of osteochondritis in elbow, and is k/a Panner’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following casts/splints is used for fracture shaft humerus?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Hanging cast is placed around fracture shaft of humerus.It is so named because it appears that humerus is hanging inside the cast. Option B-Knuckle bender splint- For median / ulnar nerve palsy. Option C- Aeroplane splint- For brachial plexus injury. Option D-Above elbow cast is used for supracondylar fracture of humerus.

choices.text: lunate dislocates anteriorly, while other carpal bones remains in place.
lunate stays in place while other carpal bones dislocates posteriorly.

questions.text: True about lunate dislocation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Lunate dislocation – lunate dislocates anteriorly, while other carpal bones remains in place. Option B-Perilunate dislocation – lunate stays in place while bones distal to lunate dislocates posteriorly. Option C-Perilunate dislocation is the more common type.

questions.text: Barton's disease is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Barton’s disease: It includes features of both rickets and scurvy. Barton fractures: are fractures of the distal radius.

choices.text: Traction, ulnar deviation, palmar flexion, POP
Traction, Palmar flexion, Ulnar deviations, POP
Traction, POP, Palmar Flexion, Ulnar deviation,
Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, traction, POP

questions.text: An old lady slipped and fell at home. She was diagnosed with a colles fracture and managed with a POP cast. What is the correct sequence of reduction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Colle’s fracture occurs due to fall on outstretched hand and is characterised by impaction,radial tilt and dorsal tilt. sequence of correction isTraction, Palmar flexion, Ulnar deviations, POP Traction is given to reduce impaction of bony fragments into each other. then,palmar flexion is done to correct dorsal tilt of colle`s fracture. then,Ulnar deviation is done to correct the radial tilt. finally POP cast is applied.

choices.text: Neurological Assessment-closed reduction- and again check neurological assessment -analgesic-cast

questions.text: Which will be the ideal treatment for distal radius fracture with Sharp ends at fracture site & soft tissue swelling was seen on wrist on X ray. What`s the further management ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) whenever we are, dealing with a fracture where there is a chance of neuro muscular injury, always assess the neurovascular injury first. Now, if we feel neuro vascular supply is intact, go for a closed reduction and then again check neurological assessment f/b analgesic and cast. Neurological Assessment-closed reduction- and again check neurological assessment -analgesic-cast

questions.text: A small child was playing with her maid where she rotated him by holding from arms. Immediately after, the child started crying. On examination, his arm was pronated. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pulled elbow is distal subluxation of the head of radius d/t which radio-carpal joint widens up. This is c/a pulled elbow or nursemaid’s elbow.
